description:
My first poke place in SF, recommended by a friend. I've tried poke before many times so I mostly know what I want in my bowl. But I thought this time I'd try something different. I ordered a Sushi Burrito. 

Service was quick and friendly. Didn't feel​ like I was rushed into ordering.  The workers who serviced and helped me out (Audrey, Joni, and Kayla ) suggested me if I wanted to do something daring, I could order everything on their shirt "Salmon Love" into a burrito. And that's what I did. Have to say...I was surprised how poke would taste so good wrapped up. Haha Portions were good, half of the burrito was enough to satisfy my hunger.
author: Robert L.

description:
Poke has been popping up all over sf and this is one of the many ones that I've been meaning to visit but everytime I'm in the area it's not open yet. Finally had a chance to go after an appointment and I have to say I was not disappointed. The shop is a bit on the small side, so it's probably better for to-go.

I opted for the classic poke bowl with ahi tuna and salmon with classic shoyu sauce. I do have to admit the portions are larger than what I had expected. There is a bit too much rice for my liking but in terms of fish and toppings there is more than enough to satisfy you. Usually I can finish a poke bowl but this one, felt like it was so much that I barely finished. Ingredients are fresh and I do love it that if you are too lazy to build your own bowl you can order a pre-set bowl which is what I did.

Parking isn't horrible during the daytime but I can imagine that night time wouldn't be great. Next time I am in the area, I'm more than willing to come back here for another poke bowl!

Total for 1: $13
author: Stella J.

description:
The place is small and does not have much seating. The servers are nice. 

The fish was fresh but they have small portions. The toppings had a good section. However,  nothing really stood out to me. The poke was just OK. If i was in the neighborhood then I might est here, but I would not come down just for the poke.
author: Michelle C.

description:
l'a Poke serves sushi burittos and poke bowls. You can either customize or get a pre-set option off the menu. 

The restaurant is quite small and there's very limited stool seating. It seems more like a take out place. The Small bowl costs $9, Large bowl costs $13, and sushi burrito costs $11. I was a little disappointed to see that the Small was limited to only 3 toppings so I probably should have went with the large. Portions were quite small in my opinion, but I guess that's typical for SF.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
I'm a fan of this place! It's very clean, the fish is always fresh and the topping selection is excellent. 

After coming a few times, I think I prefer the burrito to the bowl; it feels more substantial and filling to eat (they sometimes give small-ish scoops of protein). I also prefer the "build your own" option to selecting a premade combo, as it is cheaper and you wind up with more food ;)

The service is also great in that they will answer questions as you go, and never rush you if you don't know the "rules" of how to order or need time to make your choices. There are usually a few other people there, but it's rarely busy where you have to wait a while to eat. Look forward to returning!
author: Christine G.

description: Not bad for a poke place, but I didn't think there was anything too special about I'a Poke. I knew from previous reviews that I wouldn't have a lot of meat in my small bowl (which comes with 2 scoops of protein + 3 toppings). But even for someone like me who doesn't eat very big portions, I thought the place could have been more generous with their meat portions. I also thought I got too many toppings, which meant my bowl didn't taste very balanced. Nevertheless, I'a Poke is still an OK place for poke near Castro.
author: Connie X.

description:
While I was looking for it, I almost walked past it. It's a small little place tucked away on the street.

This was actually my first time trying poke and I was not disappointed. The women behind the counter were helpful when I decided to build my own instead of going after a pre-selected menu. They even suggested a spicy miso sauce combo which ended up making the whole dish tasty.

I ordered a smaller bowl but definitely had plenty to eat. The ingredients were extremely fresh. I went with the Tuna and Salmon this round but will definitely be back.

Like I mentioned before, it's pretty small so there is very much limited seating. I went around 5:30pm so was able to grab a spot but for the most part I saw people ordering to go.
author: Stephen P.

description: My husband loves this place, but personally I do not like Poke.  So I always go, but have never ordered anything. This last time we went I noticed shrimp was on the menu, and I love shrimp! I ended up getting a bowl with salad, teriyaki shrimp, edamame and avocado.  I don't know who was more excited that I found something yummy there for me to eat - myself or my husband!
author: Run.It.Off V.

description:
Small space, but great poke! They do sushi burritos too-- watch out Sushiritto! 

My only complaint was that the octopus was too chewy and not very flavorful. Other than that, I highly recommend this spot!
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Given with how trendy poké is nowadays it's hard to decide where to get your fix.

I'a Poke is a sushi burrito and a poké bowl spot in Castro. It's off the beaten bath on Church street but worth your while. 

They offer a selection of combo deals or build your own. I haven't tried any sushi burritos besides Sushiritto so I thought I'd give it a try. I recommend getting the Honolulu Sushi Burrito. It's loaded with a variety of protein and toppings. The nori didn't do so well in holding all the food together as it started to break apart while I ate. I'd come back to try one of their bowls but you want some wrap options, this is a good spot for it.
author: Virginia Y.

description: This poke place was pretty good but also pretty pricy. More sauce would have been nice. Also the only spicy sauce options were sriracha or mayo based. Fish quality was excellent! And the premarinated mixes were delicious! Besides that I thought the topping selection could use some additions. Most notably white/red onions and edamame.
author: Adam B.

description:
I have not been to a lot of poke places but I think this one is pretty decent and it's close by my place! 

It's hard to go wrong with poke, all you need is fresh ingredients! They will be tossed in yummy dressing anyways like spicy mayo, ponzu, or sesame shoyu. The condiments are also very tasty such as the imitation crab salad, seaweed salad, furikake, fried shallots, masago, etc.

The small bowl is pretty tiny in my opinion, and you get limited fish choices and toppings. It's probably worth getting the large bowl with 5 fish choices and unlimited condiments (it's only a couple of dollars difference). Certain toppings like mango and avocado are additional charge. 

It's a convenient place to grab lunch and bring it home, to the office or to the park if you feel like taking a break from sandwiches!
author: Sam M.

description:
Pretty good! 

I got damn near everything in that poke bowl,  and it was delicious,  substantial and had some good flavors.  Everything from jalapeño,  Wasabi,  spicy mayo,  egg,  yellow tail, salmon, tuna,  marinated tuna, brown rice,  and all the sauces. Everything was relatively fresh and the flavors were nice,  not quite Hawaiian style,  but it was still great. I do not recommend adding avocado however,  it was like $2 for a raw hard quarter of an avocado which was not worth it. 

Service was nice and very patient. 

If you like customizable bowl of poke,  and you come hungry,  this is the place to go!
author: Tina A.

description: Great poke bowl. I like it raw and tasty when it comes to my fish and veggies. Good location if your heading to Dolores Park .
author: Juan V.

description:
I've been eating a lot of poke lately and in my opinion, I'a Poke is an average place in SF for poke. The reason being is that the price is slightly above average and the scoops are very average (not as generous as some reviewers say). For instance, my friend who ordered a poke asked for salmon and most of the salmon pieces fell out of the tiny scooper as the employee was scooping so he only got one piece of salmon. The fish wasn't extraordinarily fresh or large. There are some pretty cool toppings and I like that it's unlimited for the large order (~$12.95). However, many poke places have unlimited toppings regardless of the size of your order. If you order a small poke bowl, you are only allowed a limited number of toppings. 

Personally, I enjoy other poke places in SF more such as Poketime (Inner Sunset) and Coast Poke Counter (Embarcadero) so I probably won't come back just to eat here.
author: Nicole J.

description:
First time ever coming here and I got the Honolulu with no spicy mayo and avocado added to it. Holy cow this was good. My first time ever having a sushi burrito and idk if there's going to be another place better. The meat portion is crazy and the shrimp were huge. This place is so fresh. It's very small and a whole in the wall.
Definitely a must if you've never had a sushi burrito. They got a regular because this place is the best!
author: Lambert T.

description: This is probably the best poke I've had outside of Hawaii! It was so fresh! You can create your own bowl or turn it into a sushi burrito but either way it's delicious! A great place to grab a quick bite to eat!
author: Angela Y.

description:
This is my absolute favorite poke place. I started coming here last summer and I cannot get enough of it. The prices are an average price for poke, but the portion sizes are pretty great and definitely filling. I, personally, love the sushi burrito and would argue that this place has the best sushi burrito. The fish is fresh and the toppings are delicious. You get to choose whatever you want inside your burrito which is different from sushirrito and definitely a plus.

Hands down, my favorite place to eat and favorite place for poke! I've brought a lot of friends here and they all love this place too and you can bet you'll see me back here again!
author: Jessica Z.

description: They have good portion sizes, have always been fast, and their ingredients are relatively fresh. All around decent poke, not mind blowing but a solid option at the price point (14-16 dollars for a poke bowl). They have a relatively small area inside so it's probably better to plan taking your food somewhere else to eat.
author: Caelin J.

description:
On my phone, on google maps and almost missed this spot! Stopped by to grab some food before heading to Dolores Park. 

Ordered the Honolulu sushi burrito. Pretty small spot and no line. They make the food pretty fast. 

The sushi burrito itself was okay. Plenty of fish and flavor was there. Compared to sushiritto, smaller in size. They also have customizable poke bowls.

Good spot that's walking distance to the park but I'll opt out of the burrito- maybe the poke bowl instead. Oh did I mention? The Honolulu was $13.00 (yeah...).
author: Elaine C.

description: If you want something healthy and quick this place is great.  Every time I go there I try something new but my favorite is still the Poke Bowl.
author: Parastoo E.

description:
I have not been to any other poke bowl spots but I don't need to, this place is amaaazing! Super fresh and even the small bowl can be jam packed with goodness. I like to get brown rice, spicy tuna and either shrimp or salmon marinated in spicy mayo and soy sauce, green onions, edamame, picked ginger, avocado ($1 extra), fried onions, sesame seeds, cucumbers, seaweed salad, and all kinds of other toppings. They also make sushi burritos, which I have not tried but I imagine are just as tasty. 

Given its location, it might take a little while to find parking but there have been times that my boyfriend and I have found parking right in front. They can get busy at times but the wait has never been too long every time I have gone.

I always forget to take a picture of my bowl because I'm too excited to eat but I will next time I go and post it on here
author: Janette M.

description:
My favorite poke place in SF. Can't say enough good things about these folks who are generous with their servings and it all tastes really good. 

I always do the large make your own bowl of poke and I've tried literally everything. What I recommend over everything is their marinated tuna and salmon both of which are great quality and very tasty with their sauces. 

This location is far better than their other locations.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Loved the fresh sushi burritos here! You can make your own for $11. The poke bowls are slightly pricier at $13. The service is quick and friendly. There's a few counter spots to sit at inside.

I got white rice with salmon. I really liked the sesame shoyu and spicy mayo sauce combo. I added a variety of toppings (unlimited for the burrito) including edamame, tamago (sweet egg), seaweed salad, fried onion, and sesame seed. 

Overall I'll definitely be back to try their other combos.
author: Linda X.

description:
Parking: tough around here especially on weekends

Food:
The quality of the fish is fresh and great - and pretty generous scoops (depending how busy ;) ) and there's plenty of toppings options! Dinged a star because it's on the pricier end for a poke bowl (if you're a student or on a budget)

My friend customized a burrito and said it was pretty delicious - it just seemed small to me and that a large bowl was worth it volume wise (but i also just eat a lot...)
author: Cheri C.

description: Small protein portions. Not a lot of topping options. Charge extra for Mango. Doesn't beat some other Poke places in SF that doesn't skimp out on the portions. Over priced for the amount you receive.
author: Brian J.

description:
This is becoming my favorite poke spot in/near the city. This is my girlfriend's absolute favorite place. They may not have as many variety of protein as some of the other places, but what they do have is top notch. Very fresh and unlimited toppings.

I'm simple,  always salmon and tuna and a wasabi dressing. 

Place is small, maybe 7 or 8 seats. Just come before the lunch rush and you'll be fine.

Lastly, this may matter to some, no high chairs for toddlers.
author: Jin S.

description:
Poke bowl review, will go back to try their sushi burritos.

Ordered the Aloha. You have the option of white rice, brown rice, or salad. We ordered half brown rice and half salad and felt it was the perfect combination! Flavors were good, poke was fresh and the place was clean with friendly staff.

Hope they open a store downtown so u can go their for lunch every day!
author: Mandi W.

description:
Obsessed with this place. As in one time I nearly cried when I went there only to realize it was already after 8 and it had closed for the night. 

Since it's near where we live, my boyfriend stop by at least once a week, if not more. Perhaps not the cheapest option, but certainly worth it for the freshness and healthy factor. They recently introduced a rewards program that allows you to redeem points for free beverages or free poke bowls which is amazing considering how often we go. 

What to expect on the menu: Choose from a large or small poke rice bowl or grab a sushi burrito. Large bowls give you 4 scoops of protein and unlimited toppings; small bowls come with 2 protein scoops and 3 toppings. A sushi burrito gives you 3 scoops of protein. 

I almost always stick to the rice bowls, with the sesame shoyu sauce and cilantro. Their portions are generous and all of the ingredients are fresh and delicious. Service is friendly and they're careful with food prep (e.g. changing gloves for every service).
author: Vic C.

description: We saw this spot as we were waiting for the Muni, so we decided to go in. The place is tiny and there was no line on a Sunday at noon. I took a look at the options and decided to "share" a large bowl with my friend, because neither of us were that hungry. But the bowls are absolutely miniature so sharing became kind of a joke as soon as we were given the bowl. They give you the tiniest scoops of fish (I have literally never seen an ice cream scoop that small). There was enough food for about 5 bites, so I had two bites. The fish didn't taste the most fresh, but there was nothing wrong with it. For $14+ dollars, I'd skip this place and go elsewhere for a normal quantity of good quality poke.
author: Nelya T.

description: Great fish selection and toppings. It is a little hot in the space and not much room to sit, but for takeout this place is a winner.
author: Krystal P.

description:
From the moment the person helping me finished scooping the marinated tuna, I regretted coming here. I'm a huge poke fan, and since I was in the neighborhood feelin hangry, I found that this place had great reviews so I thought I'd give it a try. 

The portions are tiiiiiny. Sure, I got a small which is the same bowl used at Poki Time and the two scoops of fish was like one scoop that I'm used to at other places. I was ready for the scooper to keep scooping, but alas. Then only three toppings? 

I'm still hungry...

If you want great quality with large quantity, I'd say make the effort to go to Poki Time. Same price, more choices, and you won't leave hungry.
author: George M.

description:
I'A POKE PRO TIPS:

1) Do not make any lame Pokemon jokes. Seriously. 

2) Skip the "sushi burrito" for the less soggy poke bowl. 

3) Decide on your base (rice/salad), fish options (yellowtail for moi, spicy tuna for the hubs), sauce and toppings (seaweed, cucumbers and tobiko please).  

4) Do not be THAT person who asks about every single topping or says things like, "I want the octopus and tuna but can you make sure that they are not touching." (Nope, not making this up. #AllTheEyeRolls)

5) Give a shoutout to the friendly staff who graciously put up with #1 and #4.
author: Amy C.

description:
Upon walking into I'a Poke we were blasted with the smell of vinegar. It smelled so badly, I was debating taking our food to-go. Thankfully, the smell died down, or our noses got used to it. Who's to say. 

We stayed and shared a Salmon Lover sushi burrito and and large poke bowl. I really enjoyed the Salmon Lover and hands down would pick this over Sushirrito. They use a crispier type of nori here that was pretty flavorful. 

I wish I could rave about the poke bowl as well, but the white rice was over-powered with vinegar (explains the smell). Aside from that, it was good but standard in comparison to other build-your-own poke joints. They have tamago as a topping here which you don't see around everywhere. Yum! 

Tip: if you're getting a poke bowl, go for large since a small limits you to three toppings only. 

I'd come back for the burritos!
author: Laverne N.

description:
I had to write a review. The place is squeaky clean, the staff is super kind and gentle, and the food is fresh, delicious with excellent sized portions.

This is the best pokey place I've eaten that to date.
author: Amethyst P.

description:
To keep it simple with bullet points...

- My bowl tasted fishy
- A teensy bit pricier than other poke places
- A size small allows only 3 toppings 
- Ordering process is annoying, as I scream over their tall glass countertop. What makes it worse is that they WROTE on their tall glass countertop making it a little hard to visibly see the toppings/what they're doing. 
- Found a little fuzzball in my bowl. I initially thought it was a bug, but after minutes of close examination, it was a fuzzball. (Maybe it came from the seaweed salad...somehow...?) 
- My bowl was DDDRRREEENCHED in sauce! Towards the end, I was grimacing at how salty each bite was. 

To sum it up, my eating companion and I quote, "This is the worst poke bowl we've ever tasted".
author: Kris C.

description:
Very small little takeaway poke/Sushhirito copycat in a great location with a few stools but mostly takeout business.

A little pricey, staff wasn't the most engaged I've met in the Castro, and the food was a mixed bag... my "burrito" was a B+ but my friends was soggy and a C-.

I'll go back to give it another chance, but this first trip... it was really a three-star could-return-but-wouldn't-miss-it kind of experience.
author: Sean B.

description:
Came by this nice poke shop after church on Sunday. The line wasn't too long and they have so many options!

I chose to get a poke bowl, and you get to pick four proteins. You can also opt to get a sushi burrito. You can do what I did and pick four different ones, but my friend got four portions of salmon, which you can do too. You also get unlimited toppings, some of which you may have to pay extra for such as avocado, but it's all clearly marked which ones you'd have to pay more for.

I got brown rice to be healthier and it was good! The large bowl was really big, and I ended up sharing with my sister and we were both so full after eating it.

It's also really easy to take to-go, as the poke bowl comes with a pretty nicely sealed container and cap. They also wrap the sushi burrito and place it in a to-go box, so you can take your food and walk on over to dolores park and have a nice picnic!
author: Theresa L.

description:
Oh
My
Gosh
This place is awesome.  Walked over from Brewcade to get goodness in my belly.  Ordered the Honolulu without shoyu sauce or seasoned seaweed.  Guess what?  The guy helping us asks me
"Do you have gluten allergies?"
My little heart leapt for joy!
I replied yes and he informed me that they had gluten free soy sauce to substitute and that the seasoned seaweed was gluten free!!!  I can't tell you how long it's been since I've had a meal that I didn't have to worry about and having a well informed server (I wish I had gotten his name!). And the burritos were done in less than 3 minutes.
These guys were on point and I just love that I was care free and worry free about what I was eating!  Thank you!!!
author: Heidi B.

description:
Great sushi burritos! I like it better here than Sushirrito.
I don't know why but it's cheaper (about $10-11) to build your own than to get the specials.

Blessed that my nori was well seasoned and crispy because I can't stand soggy seaweed.

The only thing I don't like about these type of poke places are that the fish aren't marinated because they mix the sauce and the fish in front of you. Not really "poke" in my option.
So besides the tasty nori I couldn't really taste the "sesame shoyu" sauce in my burrito. But, thats the same criticism I have with other places. I know it wouldn't be economical if they marinated every fish with every sauce. Maybe they can customize the intensity of the sauce?

I also have to agree with others that the white rice was bland and mushy. 

Soooo basically besides great service, my 3 stars were for not messing up my nori LOL
author: Grace Z.

description: This place is super cute and they have a great variety of toppings. I've grown to love poke, so I suppose it's hard to disappoint me. Prices are pretty steep, but it's sf so what do you expect.
author: Jane H.

description:
Finally got to try this place and it by far the best poke bowl I've had in the city (and I've had plenty!) - the fish was super fresh (not dull & mushy) and the shoyu poke was too legit. I don't think a lot of places outside of Hawaii get the color, flavor, and freshness right, but this place nailed it!  

I built my own bowl with shoyu poke, shrimp, salmon, and yellowtail dressed with ponzu sauce - I will definitely come here again and again!
author: Nancy G.

description:
I'm glad SF is catching up with the times and that poke spots are popping up all over the place in the bay area. I didn't get enough in my poke bowl, so that was my fault. The rice was a little mushy, but the salmon and tuna were one of the best tasting poke I have had at any location. Next time, I will certainly add more to my bowl or try the sushirito. 

Finding parking is tough. Service is great. There was no line for lunch. One thing is noticed is that they place the poke and toppings in a very organized fashion, as if plating very delicately. That's different-- other poke spots just slap it all together. I must say that it is inside for an Instagram picture.

Tip: Learn from my mistake, and add a lot of toppings!
author: Jaime F.

description:
Like Chipotle, but with raw chunks of fish instead of faux Mexican meats.  You customize either a bowl or a "burrito" (which is like an oversized sushi roll).  It seemed to be a generous portion of fish, so a nice value proposition.

Volcanorrito: Pretty stiff competition for Sushirrito.  Lots of tasty raw tuna.  The shrimp was fully cooked, like cocktail shrimp; not as impressive as the tuna.  A very generous helping of fresh avocado.  Had some nice flavoring, but wasn't overly spicy despite having jalapeño, chile powder and spicy mayo.

Poke Bowl: I was a little overwhelmed by the options.  Apparently you can choose 4 different fish options to be mixed in a sauce of your choosing.  I love the mass customization, but I feel the poke losing the opportunity to soak up the spices/sauce when it's tossed to order.  Lots of topping options.  Really liked how tamago was a free add-on.
author: Adam B.

description:
I am so happy. I had the sushi burrito with octopus and spicy tuna and honestly they have the freshest octopus I've ever had. Their seaweed was nice and crunchy, but not too salty. Every ingredient was super fresh, and left me wanting to eat another burrito.

I can't wait to come back and eat here again. Excellent service too!
author: Ethan T.

description:
4.5 STARS

Just two months ago, I was complaining (to myself) that San Francisco was so late on their poke game (Pacific Catch doesn't count). The closest place was Poke Bowl in Daly City and they're as consistent as...lets just say, your gag reflex will be tested: http://bit.ly/1UYyBwE. 

The Poke Gods have heard our prayers because just in the last several weeks, three poke bars have opened in SF; and two more are slated to open in the next several weeks! I just hope it doesn't get overly saturated like the boba shops in SF; we have like 50+ now? We, San Franciscans sure love balls in our mouth! 

I've been anticipating the opening of I'a Poke for months - driving by everyday like a stage 5 clinger stalking her ex-boyfriend. 

As of this past weekend, l'a Poke is finally open! 

l'a Poke is located in the old Chile Pies location and is currently soft opening this week from 12 pm - 7 pm (check their fb page for updates: https://www.facebook.com/iapoke/).

Just like all the other poke eateries (Pokeatery, Poke Bowl, Poki Time, and Limu & Shoyu), it's a chipotle-style, build your own poke bowl. They only have one size for $12.50 (4 scoops of protein). 

(1) Choose your BASE: white rice, brown rice (not available during soft opening), and/or kale;
(2) Choose your PROTEIN: tuna, spicy tuna, salmon, albacore, shrimp and/or octopus;
(3) Choose your SAUCE: sesame shoyu, ponzu, spicy mayo, and/or miso mayo; and
(4) Choose your TOPPINGS (unlimited during soft opening): cilantro, cucumbers, edamame, onions, pickled ginger, seasoned seaweed, radish sprouts, wakame, surimi, tamago, green leaf, white onions, green onions, masago, furikake, jalapeno, sesame seeds, fried onions, wasabi, and avocado (+$1). 

They also have sushi burritos available. Cc's accepted. 

l'a Poke is more of a to-go spot since there's limited counter seating. Parking can be an issue during the weekends but I was able to find a non-metered spot several doors down on a weekday afternoon. 

Yesterday, I ordered two poke bowls: one for linner (late lunch, early dinner) and one for lunch today at work. One bowl I ordered with half rice and kale, and the other with all kale (for today's lunch which held up well overnight). I ordered half tuna and half salmon for both bowls with spicy mayo and miso mayo plus all the toppings except cilantro: http://bit.ly/1T1yayk. 

:: P R O S ::
*Super friendly service.
*Beautiful presentation; the poke bowls are nicely assembled and sh*t is not sloppily thrown together like Poke Bowl in Daly City.
*Eco-friendly, compostable to-go containers made from plants. 
*Rice is actual seasoned sushi rice and is not served scalding hot so it doesn't warm the fish by the time you get home. 
*Really fresh fish, veggies, and toppings.
*Great topping options; I love that they offer seasoned seaweed, radish sprouts, and tamago which are not available at other poke bars. 
*Surimi (imitation crab) is counted as a free topping and not as a protein (I hope it stays this way). 
*Delicious and flavorful miso mayo sauce.

:: R O O M   F O R   I M P R O V E M E N T ::
*One of the employees forget half my toppings for my all kale bowl (cucumbers, masago, tamago, furikake, fried onions, etc) but I think he was just nervous. 
*The kale was really dry; they should lightly dress it with some vinaigrette before placing it in the to-go bowl. 
*Fish was cut a bit too large so you only get 2-3 or so cubes per a scoop (they use mini ice cream scoops).
*They could be a little more generous with their veggie toppings. 
*Veggies/toppings could be cut more smaller and thinner. I received several whole slices of white onions and thick slices of jalapeno.
*Instead of giving customers with one large quarter of an avocado, they should cut it into cubes so it's easier to eat. 

I have been eating poke bowls weekly as they cheaply satisfy my raw cravings. l'a Poke is off to a great start for their soft opening and is currently my favorite poke bar place in the SF Peninsula area after Pokeatery in San Mateo. Awesome job, guys!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
This place deserves a slow clap. I am sure every person who likes sushi has gone to a poke place sometime in their life, if you haven't... just try it! It is well worth the experience!  First off this place is small. It's extremely close to the bart station on chruch (I think) and it's on the way to dolores park from the bark. You really need to go in and get your own sushiritto. If you don't like the sushiritto at other places because it's their set menu, then go here. I have never been to a place like this one where they allow you to make your own sushiritto,  it's amazing. 

The workers are really nice. The inside is modern and cute! The portions are more than enough to fill my belly. The price of each where relatively reasonable. I hope to come again! Btw, this would be great on a sunny day at dolores park with your friends!
author: Ann N.

description: This little gem that I've found is simply the best: their poke bowls are THE BOMB! Super fresh, creative ingredients, the staff is really nice and they are very quick to serve you. The place is quite small but doesn't matter because you can also take away your bowl. I totally suggest trying it, add everything TUNA and salmon and you will not regret it for sure and of course ED (some more) MAME! It's the cool lunch place!
author: Irina P.

description: The food, wonderful and lots of toppings to add in. Love the large bowl as you can literally get all of the toppings in there, great value. The only slip, service, wow it wasn't good at all. No customer service what so ever, not helpful at all, not willing to explain anything, just the rush get you in and out attitude. I almost hesitate to return because of that alone, but man the food was good. It wasn't as bad as the soup kitchen nazi, but everyone in here seemed so dead. I get it, the food industry can eat at your soul, but if someone walks in looking like a deer in head lights, help a sister out, I'm not here to bite lol. Ok rant over, definitely a yummy spot to pick up and go. I wanted to try the burrito, but with the reviews on size I refrained. Maybe next time.
author: Guisela L.

description:
Fast casual Chipotle-like version of sushi.  You can either order a Poke Bowl or a Sushi Burrito.  You build it yourself, choosing 4 different proteins (raw fish) and an assortment of toppings, or you can go with one of their signature burritos.  The burritos are a little bit cheaper than the bowl.  

I ordered the Salmon Lover which was great.  I really liked the Sun Dried Guacamole and the Tamago.  Balanced out the flavors well and the salmon seemed pretty fresh.  I was surprised by how crispy the seaweed was despite the fact that it had been sitting with a layer of rice for a while.  I think next time, I will probably try to build my own burrito because there were some other possible toppings that seemed tempting like sprouts and fried onions (crunch!).

I came for their soft opening and it seemed like the process was a little bit less than smooth.  They will need to be more efficient for their grand opening because I am sure that they will start having lines of people!  There were three really annoying flies though that were zooming around the middle of the space.  Limited seating, but this seems more like a to-go place.  I can't wait to come back.  I still think I preferred Sushiritto's Geisha's Kiss but this is much closer, more convenient, and lets me build my own!
author: Jess Y.

description:
I came here today after church around 12:30 and it was already pretty bustling. Tiny area with some seating, but it's definitely more of a takeout place. 

The menu is packed; i wish they would create "signature" bowls so that it's easier to pick and choose from the protein and toppings. 

I ordered the salad bowl with salmon and spicy tuna, with the sesame shoyu - topped with cucumber, masago, edamame, sprouts, tamago, and pickled ginger. I wouldn't actually recommend getting pickled ginger in the bowl bc it doesn't mesh too well with the other flavors.

Ponzu is basically shoyu with a lemon zing, in case you were curious like me.
author: Juliana P.

description:
Randomly was in the mood for a poke bowl and found this place. When I first walked by, I thought they were closed because it looked rather dim from the outside. I walked closer to check it out and make sure, and to my surprise they were open. 

I wanted to be rude and eat on BART, so I got a sushi burrito called "Honolulu" for portability purposes. 

The sushi burrito was $13 plus tip, and was pretty tasty. It gets soggy and I have all these weird white stains on my jacket and jeans, and I was probably slurping loudly, but I had my headphones in so as long as I couldn't hear myself, I'm golden.

Anyways, no regrets here. I'd like to sit down and grab a San pelligrino and a poke bowl next time and really savor the food instead of inhaling it in a mad rush.
author: Grace Y.

description:
If I were to really break down my rating, it would be more like a 3/5 for the sushi burrito and a 4/5 for poke bowls. I love that for the poke bowls, if you get a large you can get as many different topping as you want. They also have a pretty good selection of fish to choose from! 

As for the sushi burrito however, I felt like of the toppings that were available, my burrito really could have used something crunchy (like lotus or taro chips or something) to break up the mostly soft texture of the entire thing. Honestly it just tasted like a poke bowl wrapped in nori to me (which, yeah, I know that's basically what this was). I think what makes sushirrito better is that the ingredients they picked to put into theirs makes a really good combination of flavors and textures, but with what's available at I'a Poke everything sort of ends up tasting pretty much the same. Still, this is a really good option for poke bowls, and also to just quickly satisfy a sushi burrito craving.
author: Stephany L.

description:
I've been here twice and both times I got the poke bowl. This place also has sushi burritos so I want to try it some day. The food is pretty pricey (~$13 for classic poke bowl), but I guess these prices are normal in the city. A large bowl definitely fills me up.
There is very little seating inside this place, so my friends and I have always walked over to Dolores Park to eat there.
author: Annie S.

description: Didn't love the fish here. Found it fatty and chewy, and was unimpressed. Also pricing and portions were not great.
author: Meaghan H.

description:
Ordered two sushi burritos (honolulu and shellfish king) -- it was okay, but expensive for what it is. I've had other sushi burritos elsewhere and this place is not on the top of my list.

I really liked the service though! People were very friendly.
author: Erika S.

description: Love Love Love. Personally I find this to be the BEST poke place in the city. Literally in love with the spicy tuna and seaweed salad. They offer bowls or burritos. Never smells fishy. Always very quick. I will gladly spend my money at this spot when ever I'm on Church. Staff is stellar as well. Stoked to see more locations popping up around the city.
author: Kalie K.

description:
I really wanted poke, but the nearest place by my office was packed, as usual. So I hopped on the M to I'a, which was the second closest poke place. 

I got the burrito since the toppings are endless (they're limited for the small bowls). I chose all salmon for my protein (you can choose 3), green onions, fried onions, edamame, seaweed salad, and tamago. I forgot about the sun-dried tomato guacamole which means I'll have to go back. The burrito was really good! Messy, but good. The salmon was fresh, and tasty with the sesame shoyu. 

I got mine to go. It's small inside with limited seating. It's kinda dark in there, too. 

There's one vegetarian bowl with tofu. Not sure if you can get it in burrito form. 

It's not too far from my office, and there wasn't any lines when I was there. I'a may be my go-to poke place when the craving hits.
author: Vira P.

description:
Love that this spot is by Dolores Park - perfect meal to grab on a sunny afternoon if you're in the area! 

Generous portions and very fresh fish. A problem that I have with other poke places is that they dress the poke with waaaaay too much sauce, but I didn't run into that at all at I'a. 

A little more pricey than some other poke places in the city but will definitely be back if I'm in the area!
author: Winnie T.

description:
Tried this place a few times but they seem to consistently be out of key ingredients (I.e. Rice) even when you get there 30 mins after opening. How do you open the doors to your poke restaurant and then 30 mins in still don't have rice? I am able to make rice at home in less than 30 mins but this place can't manage to do the same for some reason. 

The food is okay you're within a block and just want something to fill yourself with. The fish is too fishy, smells like the seafood section at an Asian grocery store. I haven't had a complete dish here since they don't stock everything they claim to have. 

I walked over to another poke place that just opened and it's much much better. Just a few blocks away from this place, lower prices too.
author: Scott T.

description: Good spot with bowls and burritos. The pre picked options are good along with the custom. Great location and easy to find parking. $12 for a large bowl with 4 protien picks.
author: John R.

description:
I leave the city for almost 7 weeks and when I get back, it turns out a slew of new poke restaurants have opened!

And I'm not mad.

Both of my trips to Kauai were partially driven by the access I'd get to fresh, delicious poke. I usually stop by a street-side poke stand immediately after leaving the airport... the resort can wait!

After sitting in a salon chair for far too long yesterday, my stomach rumblings grew as they begged for a bowl of Hawaiian-style raw fish. I walked the several blocks to l'a Poke and ordered a small bowl jam-packed with spicy tuna, shrimp, seaweed, brown rice, green onions, cilantro, sesame seeds, jalapeño, avocado and mango. 

It was beautiful, it really was. And because they're generous with their toppings, even the small size should satiate a light-to-medium hunger level. 

The fish was unbelievably fresh - no fishy taste/odor here. I'm already plotting my return for tomorrow's lunch! Healthy and flavorful, this is my kind of fast food.
author: Jelena Z.

description: Wow, loved this Poke place! Joni, Jessica and Audrey really helped with all my silly questions. The place was clean and the staff was alert and friendly. It's a small cute place tucked into the neighborhood but offers a lot of options once you're inside. The unlimited topping is a plus with the four protein options. Will be back soon!
author: Kieara L.

description: Awesome food!! Very good prices for the quality of food. If you like sushi you will love this place!!
author: Roy M.

description:
I really like I'a Poke, it's close to my house and the people who work there are pretty friendly.

After ordering the signature Aloha bowl I've never felt the need or desire to order anything else. It's perfect, delish and filling.

I do kinda wish on busy days they'd have different lines for ordering. One line for build your own, and another for signature dishes. 

It's a bit pricier but the quality is top notch. It's a tiny spot so I've only eaten in once, way more comfy to head to the park.
author: Margaret I.

description: This place has some of the highest quality fish I've had at any sushi or poke establishment in SF. I always get the salmon and yellowtail; they are just amazing. The portions are pretty generous and the prices aren't bad, either. It's the perfect place to go for a high-quality, healthy lunch.
author: David B.

description: A great poke stop in SF. I'm a big poke fan and this place is of pretty great quality!
author: Alejandra R.

description: We only came here to try the sushirrito and it was great. Not disappointed in the slightest. It's more of a take out place since the building space is super small and it would be a tight squeeze during busy hours.
author: Anna L.

description: I absolutely love this place! Since moving out of the city I'm bummed not to have such a great place to go to for poke so every time I come out to SF I have to swing by and grab a poke burrito! Their staff is friendly and the place is always very clean. Best of all, the portions are perfect!!
author: Claudia M.

description: My boyfriend and I ordered poke bowls through one of those apps that delivers to you just recently. The price was pretty reasonable for the amount of food that you get and the poke bowl itself was awesome! I will definitely be ordering from them again soon.
author: Laina C.

description: Loved the spicy tuna and salmon with the sesame sauce! So happy that a great poke place opened up nearby!
author: Rishabh G.

description: Super great little joint for a quick takeout sushi burrito. I opted for their Honolulu burrito which was delish, fresh fish, though could have more of a kick to it as it's supposed to have spicy mayo and wasabi. My companion did a make your own and it was very good and they gave him great suggestions in making it. Average prices. Not really a place for eating in though they do have a counter you can sit at.
author: Amanda L.

description:
I love poke and this place is my favorite outside of Hawaii. I find their options are more traditional than other poke bowl places - for instance you won't find bacon as an optional topping. I like this. The fish is fresh, the staff is warm, and the environment is very clean. Only suggestion I would give them is to have hot green tea available and to stay open later!
Enjoy!
author: Jennifer R.

description:
At the end of the day, I find all new poke places rather similar: bouge Chipotle, with its own set of pros and cons, wholesomely satisfying but not quite perfect. Seeing that I'a doesn't boast anything particularly earth-shattering (or should I say tsunami-inducing...for Hawaiian food?), I will be concise in my run-down:

(+)'s
- Tamago!! Perhaps the highlight of my visit. It's a little dry and rubbery, definitely not as refined as tamago of upscale sushi places, but nonetheless a nice addition to a poke bowl. (Also very happy this doesn't cost extra, given we are in a city where fried eggs on burgers are typically an additional ~$2)
- A variety of toppings, including a creamy delicious crab salad. I shamelessly and greedily asked for all the toppings except guac :3
- Sushi burrito options: I opted for the bowl, since the burrito is rice only without the salad option. Plus, in pictures it looked significantly smaller than sushirritos.
- Charming whole-in-the-wall with aesthetic decor, including IA POKE in hip brass letters and patches of plastic grass. Though SF purists likely condemn this shiny new poke bar as a product of gentrification

(-)'s
- Fish quality is alright. I would not call myself a sashimi expert, but in my opinion it seemed seemed too fishy and not as fresh as other poke places I've visited. Also, the store and Facebook page mention nothing about sourcing, which makes me question their philosophy and how they ensure quality. My favorite in the Bay is Aloha Fresh, which flies in their fish from Hawaii!
- Sauce could use more kick. I could hardly taste the wasabi in the wasabi shoyu, while at Poki Time the wasabi sauce (delightfully) set my pants on fire. The side of wasabi seemed diluted as well. 
- Kale. Not sure this is optimal for poke, as it's a little rough and clumpy. I think mixed greens would blend in better. 
- Pricey-ish. They only have one size, $10.50 burrito with 3 scoops, or $12.50 bowl with 4 scoops (and it's small scoops by the way). I guess anything under ~$20 is reasonable by SF standards, but ~$14 for a grab-and-go... seems a bit high for a cafe/fast-food meal. 

The verdict? Not bad! Great to have another poke place with its unique features, in a part of the city that's quite convenient for picking up a quick, hearty, healthy-ish bite.
author: Edna C.

description:
Tips:

4 scoops of proteins for a bowl
3 scoops of proteins for a sushi burrito

Conveniently located very close to Dolores park so a great grab and go meal for a great day at the park.

---------------------------------------------------------

I'm so glad that I found this convenient poke place close to Dolores Park. My friends and I made a pit-stop here before heading to the park for a relaxing Sunday. It's a relatively healthy and portable meal for the park. There's even a sushi burrito option!

You can choose between white rice, brown rice, or salad for your base. What sets I'a poke from other poke places that I have been to is the variety in the salad. Usually it's a Spring Mix from the grocery store, but I'a poke brings in all variety of greens. (Collard greens, kale, spring mix, etc.) For all the health nuts out there, the salad is a true power salad mix.

The fish was very fresh and the sauces were very tasty with my poke bowl. Highly recommend dropping by for a meal. I definitely want to come back to try the sushi burritos!
author: Alice H.

description:
So great!

I'a Poke isn't officially open yet, but having put off a giant poke bowl craving for the past few weeks, I couldn't resist treating myself to a post-run poke bowl today.

It's a tiny spot, and I can only imagine that it'll get more and more crowded as word gets out, so plan for take-out (it's just a short walk to either Duboce or Dolores if picnics are your thing!). You can choose either a sushi burrito or a bowl. Bowls come with 4 scoops of protein, and burritos come with 2.

In my bowl, I got double salmon and double tuna on rice with spicy mayo as my choice of sauce. THE BEST PART is the unlimited toppings. I topped my bowl with cucumbers, edamame, fried onion, seaweed salad, furikake, green onions, masago, seaweed salad, crab meat, tamago, wakame, and sesame. By the time they were done making my bowl, it was packed full of colorful, fresh ingredients.

Needless to say, the bowl was AWESOME. It was such a nice change of pace from my usual takeout choices, and I thought it was a great deal for the price. Can't wait to come back and fingers crossed that it only gets better from here when they officially open!
author: Kelly R.

description: I like this place!  I went by for the first time and tried their poke salad.  You pick your fish and proteins and add your vegetables, and you've got quite the meal!  It is light, healthy, fresh and filling - I can't wait to go back!  I had to hurry up and eat mine because we were going to the movies, but I am bookmarking this place to go back too.  Yes!
author: Maile N.

description:
Poke bowls are one of my fave food items at the moment. I was really excited to try this place, but ended up not being very impressed. Disclaimer: I've been to some of the best poke places in Socal, so my bar is set pretty high!

This is a tiny place with very little seating. It's a bit on the pricey side ($13) but the bowl is large, and you do get a lot of toppings. Something in my bowl tasted not-so-fresh, but I couldn't identify what it was; possibly the shrimp. What disappointed me the most was how little sauce they put in. I got my bowl with salad rather than rice, and there was so little sauce (despite choosing 3 of the sauce options), that I ate most of the salad, fish, and toppings completely dry! I asked for soy sauce packets so I could at least dip in soy sauce and wasabi, but that's not how a poke bowl should be eaten!

One of the best things about poke bowls is the sauce. The items are usually tossed in the different sauces, so that you're enjoying a well-blended combo of fish in that delicious spicy mayo or ponzu. I understand some people may like less sauce if they're being health-conscious, so if you're trying to cater to them, maybe offer a heavy, medium, or light option. Who knows, perhaps it was fluke that my bowl wasn't great. But overall, I ended up feeling unsatisfied after my meal.
author: Kavita S.

description:
Cool, I'm a fan! So My boyfriend and I are poke lovers, and we had to check this place out during its soft opening--and I'm glad we did!

We both had their poke bowls, and I think it's around $13 for the bowl--which is a great price, considering you get 4 scoops of protein and unlimited toppings (avocado/guacamole is extra), I think it's a great deal. The fish is incredibly fresh, and they have a few different sauce options you can go for. 

Besides the fresh fish (this is easy, either you have fresh fish or you don't), it's the toppings that sold it for me. They have a huge variety of toppings and you can get as much as you want too. They have two different kinds of seaweed (one seasoned, one not), and two different avocado options (one is just plain avocado, and one is their sun-dried guacamole). I recommend the guacamole--it's rather unique compared to the other poke places in the peninsula, and it's so good! My only gripe with that is I wish they had given me more guacamole.

One star off for the slow service. There were only 4 people ahead of us when we went, but for some reason, we waited in line for about 15-20 minutes. There were 3 employees working in a rather small space, so I'm not sure what took so long. But this will not keep me from coming back--it also was during the soft opening, so I'm sure they'll get better. I'll post an updated review on that later.
author: Bettina P.

description:
I was excited to see a new business go into the original chile pie place and saw they were finally open. Came in just after noon and there was a line already. It's a small place and limited seating 
  I decided to go with the bowl and I got half brown rice and salad. You choose what proteins you want - I got spicy tuna, shrimp and albacore tuna the sauce - spicy mayo ( you get a choice of 4 different sauces) then as many toppings as you want ! It's a good size bowl and my combinations were delicious it came out to about $13.39. It did take a while but I think it's just opened and eventually it will speed up I know I will be going back for sure good fresh tasty food and nice service I think this will be a go to take out spot for me when I have a craving for it ! Also they have sushi burritos that look really good !!!
author: lyn m.

description: Solid portions, solid fish, solid lunch/dinner. The build your own bowl option is fantastic and you basically can customize your dream bowl and be happy for days.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I've dropped by here a couple of times already and didn't realize it was their soft opening. Now that they just had their grand opening, I'm sad because now everyone will be flocking here. It's hard to find a sushi burrito place outside of the Fi-Di so I'm thrilled they opened. They have great protein options and add ins, including tamago that I don't see too often, if at all. 

My bowls are usually pretty generous and I end up saving some for later. The sushi burritos are good and cans get pretty stuffed, but my preference are for the bowls. My daughter is big on the burritos however, so I know this will be her preferred poke place over all the others right now. 

Staff are pretty nice. I only wish they had more space for seating. Parking is going to be a b, so if you can walk or take transit or uber, do it. Nothing worse than circling and seeing a line start to form and get longer.
author: Maria S.

description:
Great fun, casual, delicious place! Found it from Hoodline.com just a few days after its soft opening.

For the poke bowl, you get to choose 4 different proteins - I chose salmon, octopus, tuna, and shrimp. Add as many toppings as you want. (They are super generous with the toppings!) Got it all over brown rice (you can also choose white). Everything was fresh, fast, and delicious! 

I honestly can't wait to come back. Great place to meet a friend for a quick bite to eat before heading out for drinks. I will also be stopping by and getting some bowls to go. 

Love love LOVE this place!
author: Jaching H.

description: Best place for a build your own burrito! The selection was great and service was quick. Wish I lived closer!
author: Macee L.

description: Came in here today for some lunch. The sushiritto is a very nice size. Unlimited after you choose your protein, you have a choice of toppings. Well, not unlimited or else you won't be able to close your burrito. I chose Hamachi, seasoned tuna and octopus as my protein and topped it with ocean salad, green onions, fried onions and masago. It came to a little over $12, not including tip.  Everything was very delicious and filled me up. Service is very friendly too.
author: Kenson K.

description: Poke bowl was good! I got the Tango one. Staff was extremely friendly and gave me good insight on what Signature Poke bowl to get. I was very satisifed! The fish was extremely fresh!
author: James D.

description: The poke was delicious, and the variety of toppings is great. It's a little pricy, though, with my large bowl coming out to $14. I would highly recommend getting as many of the toppings as possible because without them, the price point would not be worth it.
author: Camille J.

description: Friendly service, and quality, fresh ingredients make this a tasty spot off Market St. Decent portion size - was able to get 2 meals out of it.
author: Anna C.

description: Best poke in the city. Fresh fish and the best side choices. Really good deal for the price and their service is always top notch.
author: Grace L.

description: Love this place. Not just because it's close to my house, but it actually has a great selection of poke and lots of topping choices. They offer sushirittos if your in to that sort of thing, but I tend to order my poke over greens. Good flavor sauces too!
author: Claudia A.

description:
Best poke place in the city. These guys know their poke and do it really well. We get the large bowl with 4 huge scoops of fish and their spicy mayo and soy sauce. Huge helpings, and great flavor and high quality fish. I also really like their version of the egg which is amazing. 

I highly recommend. Plus their staff is amazing.
author: Sean K.

description:
Being from Seattle, my Poke options are pretty limited, so after skimming through reviews on a handful of Poke spots in SF, we decided to stop by and try out I'A Poke. The location is a small nicely decorated little shop with a few table tops for eating your poke. Like most Poke spots, they have a Chipotle-style make your own bowl/burrito bar, or you're given a list of signature burrito combos to choose from.

We both opted for making our own bowls and found the process to be a easy going, although the glass is hard to quickly skim thru options as you're ordering. On a whole, we loved the bowls, the protein was very fresh and coming from Seattle, the avocado portion was great for the additional dollar. We did think the whole bowl itself was more on the expensive side by a few dollars, but the quality of the bowl made up for the price premium. I did notice that it was hard for them to maintain protein portion control with their small ice cream scoopers. They also have a huge portion of rice for their bowls in comparison to everything else you receive, as we only ate half of the rice in our bowls before finishing all of the toppings and fish.

Overall, with a few small changes, it's a great poke spot and we will definitely be back for more before we head back to Seattle.
author: Henderson N.

description: A little expensive, but higher quality than some other poke places. I got a small poke bowl with brown rice - salmon and octopus - sesame shoyu sauce - cucumber, seaweed salad, and tamago. I enjoyed every bite of it. My favorite part was the octopus   4 stars for the price; other than that, customer service and food are great
author: Jia Mei F.

description: Honolulu sushi burrito is absolutely amazing! I've tried many sushi burritos and this is definitely the best in the city.  Very fresh fish. Super easy, no long lines. Perfect!
author: Kerry G.

description: one of the many reasons I love SF.  kind of a hole in the wall. but, it's sooo good. great prices.  delicious, fresh ingredients.
author: Shane T.

description:
So let me start off by saying that I am a native born and raised in the bay area. Throughout the entire Bay, I would have to drive up to Sacramento to have some poke. When this place open, I must say I was very pleased. Their customer service was nice by greeting and making sure you get what you want. The seafood was fresh with many options to choose from.    

This is the spot to go in sf for some some poke bowls and sushi burritos ! 

Must try 

Thanks guys for opening a spot in the bay. .. finally !!
author: Le I.

description: The poke bowls are delicious, fresh, and flavorful with large portions. The small bowl comes with 2 scopes of fish but the bowl is pretty small. The large bowl comes with 4 scopes of fish and unlimited toppings and much more worth it in my opinion. Wish it had some other common toppings like corn but overall a very satisfying and filling meal!
author: Kelly Z.

description: Super yummy and good portion sizes.  The fish was fresh and the rice was cooked perfectly.
author: Napoleon R.

description: Great poké spot! Lots of variety, you can make your own bowls or burrito with a choice of white or. Town rice. Or they have specials on their menu which you can order. Highly recommend the Honolulu Burrito, so delicious.
author: Ghazal S.

description: This place is the best. Very delicious. I recommend Shellfish King. Come hungry and leave full.
author: Ray O.

description:
Small little place, no room to eat inside so plan on walking out with your food. 

As far as the poké goes, it was okay but not great. Everything in the bowl had a weird consistent taste to it, might have been their spicy mayo sauce but it was very unpleasant. It also tastes like they put lime on their avocado, which was disgusting frankly. 

Decent selection of toppings but could be more. They are very stingy with the protein and anything else you ask for. We asked for sriracha and got a little cup with about an 1/8" of sauce in it - we usually go though a whole little cup at other poké places so this was almost a joke. Total price for two large bowls after a tip was $40 - a little on the high side compared to other poké places. 

Service was fine, no complaints there. 

I've been to quite a few poké places in the Bay Area so I know what I like and what a good portion looks like, this place was too lacking for me. Won't be going back. 

If you're looking for great Bay Area poké definitely give Pokédon in San Ramon a try, it's worth the drive and my absolute favorite poké place in the whole bay. I've even driven to San Mateo and San Jose for poké and nothing beats Pokédon so far.
author: Andy K.

description: The sushi burritos here are personal and can be suited to your liking however you may choose. I like the concept of making your own sushi burrito rather than choosing a "special" from the menu. The toppings and seafood here are fresh and there is more variety in what you can put in your sushi burrito than most other sushi burrito places. I stuffed mine with tamago, masago, furikake, octopus, spicy tuna, salmon, cucumber, avocado, and a lot of other toppings that I forgot... There was so many. I will definitely be back when I am in SF again.
author: Kathy H.

description: This is a trendy addition to an already trendy area of town. They ship in fresh fish from Hawaii overnight, so you don't get that nasty fishy aftertaste. Bowls and burritos are reasonably priced and filling. Service friendly and prompt. The place is kind of small and so they have limited seating.
author: Long C.

description:
Star Rating 1-5

Staff Friendliness: 5
Staff Knowledge: 5
Staff Efficiency: 5
Transaction Time: 5
Order Wait Time: 5
Register Counter Cleanliness: 5
Kitchen / Prep Area Cleanliness: 5
Dining Area Cleanliness: 5
